screens.headline: Right prediction, wrong timing = $0
screens.text: You predicted TSLA would hit $300. It did... 3 days after your options expired. You were RIGHT but made zero. Expiration selection isn't about predicting the future - it's about giving yourself time to BE right.

screens.headline: The Expiration Timeline
screens.text: WEEKLIES = 0-14 days (high risk, theta acceleration). MONTHLIES = 30-90 days (balanced, most popular). QUARTERLIES = 90-120 days (slower pace). LEAPS = 12+ months (behaves like stock). Choose based on your catalyst timing and risk tolerance. More time = more premium but more safety.

cards.example: TSLA earnings in 3 days? Buy weekly call. Fast theta, cheap premium, binary outcome. 80% expire worthless. High risk/reward.

cards.definition: Standard options, third Friday of each month
cards.example: Think stock rises over next 2 months? Buy 60-day call. Enough time to be right, not overpaying for excess time. Sweet spot for most traders.
Bullish on AI for 2 years? Buy NVDA Jan 2027 call. Acts like stock ownership but cheaper (delta ~0.80). Lower risk, lower reward.

screens.headline: Expiration Week Dynamics - The Final 7 Days
screens.text: 0-7 DTE = Options go CRAZY. GAMMA EXPLOSION makes prices swing wildly. THETA ACCELERATION means you lose $100+/day. Professionals close most positions by 7 DTE despite remaining value. Why? The risk (gamma) outweighs the reward (remaining theta). This is when options become gambling, not trading.

cards.definition: Gamma (rate of delta change) goes parabolic in final 7 days
cards.example: 45 DTE: gamma = 0.02 (stable). 3 DTE: gamma = 0.25 (explosive). $1 stock move = delta swings 25 points. Your P/L whipsaws $100+ per hour.

cards.definition: 80% of option value decays in final 30 days, 50% in final 7 days
cards.example: Your $5 option loses $0.10/day at 45 DTE. At 5 DTE? Loses $1/day. 10x faster decay. Clock is ticking LOUD.

cards.definition: Stock 'camps' at your strike price into expiration = assignment uncertainty
cards.example: You sold $100 put, stock hovering $99.95-$100.05 all Friday. Will you be assigned? Don't know until Monday. Stressful limbo.

cards.definition: Many pros close spreads/positions by 7 days before expiration
cards.example: You sold spread for $1 credit, it's worth $0.20 now (80% profit), 6 days left. Close it! Remaining $0.20 isn't worth gamma risk.

screens.question: You sold an iron condor for $2.00 credit. It's now worth $0.30 (85% profit captured). There are 5 days left. What should you do?
options: Hold to expiration - squeeze out last $0.30
Close now - 85% profit is excellent, avoid gamma risk
screens.explanation_correct: Professional decision! You captured 85% of max profit ($1.70 of $2.00). Holding for last $0.30 exposes you to gamma explosions - one whipsaw could cost you $500. Pros take 80-85% profit and move on. 'Pigs get fat, hogs get slaughtered.'
screens.explanation_wrong: This is where beginners get burned. You banked $1.70. Holding for $0.30 more = greed. Gamma risk in final 5 days can turn your $1.70 winner into a $500 loser in ONE move. Professional rule: Take 80%+ profit and exit. Protect your wins!

screens.question: Why do gamma explosions happen in the final week?
options: Less time = bigger delta swings per stock move = more volatility
Theta and gamma are not related
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly! With 45 DTE, $1 stock move = small delta change (time cushion absorbs it). With 3 DTE, that same $1 move = HUGE delta swing (no time left). Options become binary (win/lose) instead of gradual. This creates wild price swings = gamma explosion!
screens.explanation_wrong: It's mathematical. Gamma = rate of delta change. Near expiration, options go from ATM (50% chance) to ITM (100%) or OTM (0%) FAST. Small stock moves = big delta swings = big P/L swings = volatility. This is gamma explosion - it's math, not manipulation.

screens.headline: Expiration Week Risk Calculator
screens.description: See how risk/reward changes as expiration approaches

screens.headline: Think of it like shipping packages
screens.text: You need to send a package. Three shipping options with different delivery times and prices...

reveal_sections.label: Overnight shipping (Weeklies - 1-7 days)
reveal_sections.content: Expensive per day ($50), but package arrives FAST. Use only when you MUST have it tomorrow (earnings, Fed decision). Miss the window = wasted money. High stress.

reveal_sections.label: Standard shipping (Monthlies - 30-60 days)
reveal_sections.content: Moderate cost ($20), arrives in reasonable time. Most flexible. Even if delayed 1-2 weeks, still arrives. This is 60-90 day options - enough time to be right.

reveal_sections.label: Slow boat shipping (LEAPS - 1+ year)
reveal_sections.content: Cheap per day ($5), but takes forever. Use when NOT urgent (long-term conviction). Package could get lost, but you have time to resend.

reveal_sections.label: This is expiration selection
reveal_sections.content: Match timeframe to your catalyst. Known event (earnings) = weeklies. Uncertain timing (sector rotation) = monthlies. Long thesis (AI boom) = LEAPS.

screens.question: AAPL earnings are in 2 days. You're very bullish. Which expiration makes most sense?
options: Weeklies expiring in 3 days after earnings
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect! Known catalyst (earnings in 2 days) = use shortest expiration needed. Weeklies give you exposure to the move at lowest cost. No need to pay for 45 extra days you don't need. Match expiration to catalyst!
screens.explanation_wrong: When catalyst is KNOWN (earnings in 2 days), use short expiration. Why pay for 45 days when the move happens in 2? Weeklies expiring 3 days out capture the earnings pop at minimal cost. Don't overpay for time you won't use.

screens.question: You think EVs will boom over the next year, but timing is uncertain. Best expiration?
screens.explanation_correct: Smart for uncertain timing! 90-180 days gives you room to be right without overpaying. Could also use 1-year LEAPS for very long thesis. Avoid weeklies/monthlies when timing unknown - theta will kill you if the move takes 4 months.
screens.explanation_wrong: Unknown timing = buy more time. 30-60 days works if you think move is 'within 2 months.' But 'boom over next year' suggests longer (90-180 days or LEAPS). Give yourself cushion - better to overpay for time than run out of time.

screens.question: You're learning options and making frequent mistakes. Which expiration gives you most forgiveness?
screens.explanation_correct: Great for learners! 60-90 days gives you time to see your thesis play out AND recover from timing mistakes. Weeklies expire before you learn anything. LEAPS are expensive to experiment with. 60-90 days = training wheels with enough time.
screens.explanation_wrong: When learning, you WILL be wrong about timing. 60-90 day options give you room for error. Weeklies expire too fast (you're still figuring it out). LEAPS cost too much for experiments. Start with monthlies, graduate to weeklies once you have edge.

screens.question: A stock's options chain shows: 7-day $2, 45-day $5, 365-day $15. You're bullish for 3 months. Which is best value?
screens.explanation_correct: Best match! 45-day ($5) covers your 3-month thesis at reasonable cost. 7-day = you'd need to roll 12+ times = $24+ total = more expensive. 365-day = overpaying for 9 extra months you don't need ($15 vs $5). Match expiration to thesis!
screens.explanation_wrong: Calculate cost vs time: 7-day needs ~12 rolls to cover 3 months = $24 total + commissions. 365-day = paying $15 for 12 months when you only need 3. 45-day = $5 for perfect time window. Match the option to your timeline, don't under or overpay.

screens.question: You have $1,000 to deploy on 60-day calls ($5 each). How many contracts can you buy? (Number only)
screens.hint: Each contract = $5 √ó 100 shares. How many can you afford?
screens.explanation: $5 premium √ó 100 = $500 per contract. $1,000 √∑ $500 = 2 contracts. Remember to always multiply by 100! Many beginners see $5 and think the contract costs $5 total. It's $500.

screens.question: It's Monday. Your weekly options expire Friday. Stock hasn't moved. Theta is -$75/day. What do you do?
options: Hold to Friday - it might move!
screens.explanation_correct: Cut and run! Theta at -$75/day √ó 4 days = you'll lose $300 more by Friday even if stock doesn't move. You're in the theta death spiral. Sell now, take the L, move to better opportunity. Hope is not a strategy.
screens.explanation_wrong: Math is brutal here: 4 days left, theta -$75/day = you'll bleed $300 by Friday. Stock needs to move $300 just to break even on time decay PLUS the move you need for profit. Probability is against you. Professional traders cut weekly losers fast.

cards.back: Weeklies: Known catalyst in 1-7 days. Monthlies: Directional thesis over 1-3 months. Quarterlies: Uncertain timing, 3-6 month view. LEAPS: Long-term conviction, 1-2 year thesis. Match expiration to catalyst!

Avoid buying options with <30 days unless you have specific near-term catalyst. Theta accelerates after 30 days. Exception: earnings, Fed meetings, product launches. Otherwise, give yourself 60+ days.

cards.front: Expiration week (0-7 DTE) - why so dangerous?
cards.back: GAMMA EXPLOSION = wild price swings. THETA ACCELERATION = lose $100+/day. PIN RISK = assignment uncertainty. Professional rule: Close positions with 80%+ profit captured by 7 DTE. Risk > Reward in final week!

cards.front: Rolling options - when does it make sense?
cards.back: Roll when: 1) Thesis intact but need more time, 2) Can roll for credit/small debit, 3) >30 days left on new expiration. Don't roll: 1) Down 50%+ (accept loss), 2) Thesis broken, 3) Just hope.
